madkitgroupextension.kernel

Class Group

  • java.lang.Object
    • madkitgroupextension.kernel.AbstractGroup
      • madkitgroupextension.kernel.Group
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Serializable, Cloneable

    public final class Group
extends AbstractGroup
    MadKitGroupExtension aims to encapsulate MadKit in order to extends the agent/group/role principle by giving the possibility to the user to work with a hierarchy of groups. So one group can have one or more subgroups. These last groups can have also subgroups, etc. Such groups are represented by the class Group. One group can represent itself, but also its subgroups already handled by MadKit.
    Since:
    MadKitGroupExtension 1.0
    Version:
    1.0
    Author:
    Jason Mahdjoub
    See Also:
    AbstractGroup, MultiGroup, Serialized Form

    • Constructor Detail

      • Group

        public Group(String _community,
             String... _groups)
        Construct a group within a community and a path of groups. This constructor has the same effect than Group(false, false, null, false, _community, _groups). Here a typical example : 
         Group g=new Group("My community", "My group", "My subgroup 1", "My subgroup 2");
        The created group "My subgroup 2" is contained into the group "My subgroup 1" which is contained on the group "My group", which is contained into the community "My community". Through the function getPath(), you can observe the used String path (containing '/' characters) into MadKit for this group. To convert a String path to a Group class, use the function getGroupFromPath(String, String) or this constructor as follows : 
         String MyPath="/My group/My subgroup 1/My subgroup 2"
 Group g=new Group("My community", MyPath);
        This is the only way to introduce a '/' character into this constructor.
        Parameters:
        _community - the community
        _groups - the path of groups
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if a group name is empty, or if a group name contains a ';' character.
        Since:
        MadKitGroupExtension 1.0
        See Also:
        Group(boolean, boolean , Gatekeeper, String, String...)

      • Group

        public Group(boolean _useSubGroups,
             String _community,
             String... _groups)
        Construct a group within a community and a path of groups. This constructor has the same effect than Group(_useSubGroups, false, null, false, _community, _groups). Here a typical example : 
         Group g=new Group(false, "My community", "My group", "My subgroup 1", "My subgroup 2");
        The created group "My subgroup 2" is contained into the group "My subgroup 1" which is contained on the group "My group", which is contained into the community "My community". The obtained group does not represent its subgroups. Through the function getPath(), you can observe the used String path (containing '/' characters) into MadKit for this group. To convert a String path to a Group class, use the function getGroupFromPath(String, String) or this constructor as follows : 
         String MyPath="/My group/My subgroup 1/My subgroup 2"
 Group g=new Group(false, "My community", MyPath);
        This is the only way to introduce a '/' character into this constructor.
        Parameters:
        _useSubGroups - is set to true, the current group will represent itself, but also its subgroups. When using subgroups, an activator (for example) can handle a set of agents which are part of this group and its subgroups. see getRepresentedGroups(KernelAddress) for more information.
        _community - the community
        _groups - the path of groups
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if a group name is empty, or if a group name contains a ';' character.
        Since:
        MadKitGroupExtension 1.0
        See Also:
        Group(boolean, boolean , Gatekeeper, String, String...)

      • Group

        public Group(boolean _useSubGroups,
             boolean _isDistributed,
             String _community,
             String... _groups)
        Construct a group within a community and a path of groups. This constructor has the same effect than Group(_useSubGroups, isDistributed, null, false, _community, _groups). Here a typical example : 
         Group g=new Group(false, false, "My community", "My group", "My subgroup 1", "My subgroup 2");
        The created group "My subgroup 2" is contained into the group "My subgroup 1" which is contained on the group "My group", which is contained into the community "My community". The obtained group does not represent its subgroups. He is not distributed through several instances of MadKit into a network. Through the function getPath(), you can observe the used String path (containing '/' characters) into MadKit for this group. To convert a String path to a Group class, use the function getGroupFromPath(String, String) or this constructor as follows : 
         String MyPath="/My group/My subgroup 1/My subgroup 2"
 Group g=new Group(false, false, "My community", MyPath);
        This is the only way to introduce a '/' character into this constructor.
        Parameters:
        _useSubGroups - is set to true, the current group will represent itself, but also its subgroups. When using subgroups, an activator (for example) can handle a set of agents which are part of this group and its subgroups. see getRepresentedGroups(KernelAddress) for more information.
        _isDistributed - tell if the group is distributed through several instances of MadKit into a network.
        _community - the community
        _groups - the path of groups
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if a group name is empty, or if a group name contains a ';' character.
        Since:
        MadKitGroupExtension 1.0
        See Also:
        Group(boolean, boolean, madkit.kernel.Gatekeeper, String, String...)

      • Group

        public Group(boolean _useSubGroups,
             boolean _isDistributed,
             Gatekeeper _theIdentifier,
             String _community,
             String... _groups)
        Construct a group within a community and a path of groups. This constructor has the same effect than Group(_useSubGroups, isDistributed, _theIdentifier, false, _community, _groups). Here a typical example : 
         Group g=new Group(false, false, null, "My community", "My group", "My subgroup 1", "My subgroup 2");
        The created group "My subgroup 2" is contained into the group "My subgroup 1" which is contained on the group "My group", which is contained into the community "My community". The obtained group does not represent its subgroups. He is not distributed through several instances of MadKit into a network. No Gatekeeper is given. Through the function getPath(), you can observe the used String path (containing '/' characters) into MadKit for this group. To convert a String path to a Group class, use the function getGroupFromPath(String, String) or this constructor as follows : 
         String MyPath="/My group/My subgroup 1/My subgroup 2"
 Group g=new Group(false, false, null, "My community", MyPath);
        This is the only way to introduce a '/' character into this constructor.
        Parameters:
        _useSubGroups - is set to true, the current group will represent itself, but also its subgroups. When using subgroups, an activator (for example) can handle a set of agents which are part of this group and its subgroups. see getRepresentedGroups(KernelAddress) for more information.
        _isDistributed - tell if the group is distributed through several instances of MadKit into a network.
        _theIdentifier - any object that implements the Gatekeeper interface. If not null, this object will be used to check if an agent can be admitted in the group. When this object is null, there is no group access control.
        _community - the community
        _groups - the path of groups
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if a group name is empty, or if a group name contains a ';' character.
        Since:
        MadKitGroupExtension 1.0
        See Also:
        Gatekeeper

      • Group

        public Group(boolean _isDistributed,
             Gatekeeper _theIdentifier,
             boolean _isReserved,
             String _community,
             String... _groups)
        Construct a group within a community and a path of groups. * Here a typical example : 
         Group g=new Group(false, null, false, "My community", "My group", "My subgroup 1", "My subgroup 2");
        The created group "My subgroup 2" is contained into the group "My subgroup 1" which is contained on the group "My group", which is contained into the community "My community". The obtained group does not represent its subgroups. He is not distributed through several instances of MadKit into a network. No Gatekeeper is given. Through the function getPath(), you can observe the used String path (containing '/' characters) into MadKit for this group. To convert a String path to a Group class, use the function getGroupFromPath(String, String) or this constructor as follows : 
         String MyPath="/My group/My subgroup 1/My subgroup 2"
 Group g=new Group(false, false, null, "My community", MyPath);
        This is the only way to introduce a '/' character into this constructor.
        Parameters:
        _isDistributed - tell if the group is distributed through several instances of MadKit into a network.
        _isReserved - tell if the group does not authorize other instances with the same group
        _theIdentifier - any object that implements the Gatekeeper interface. If not null, this object will be used to check if an agent can be admitted in the group. When this object is null, there is no group access control.
        _community - the community
        _groups - the path of groups
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if a group name is empty, or if a group name contains a ';' character.
        Since:
        MadKitGroupExtension 1.0
        See Also:
        Gatekeeper

      • getPath

        public String getPath()
        The path of a group is used transparently by MadKitGroupExtension as being the real group name used in MadKit. If a group A is in a group B, which have no parent group, than the path of A will be '/B/A/' and the path of B will be '/B/'.
        Returns:
        the path of this group.
        Since:
        MadKitGroupExtension 1.0

      • getSubGroup

        public Group getSubGroup(String... _groups)
        Returns a subgroup contained on this group, or on one of its subgroups. This function is the same call than getSubGroup(false, _groups) Here a simple example : 
                Group a=new Group("My community", "A");
  Group aa=new Group("My community", "A", "A");
  Group ab=new Group("My community", "A", "B");
  Group aba=new Group("My community", "A", "B", "A");
  
  Group subgroup=ab.getSubGroup("A");
        On this example, the group subgroup is the same group than aba Through the function getPath(), you can observe the used String path (containing '/' characters) into MadKit for this group. To convert a String path to a Group class, use this function as follows : 
         String MySubPath="/My subgroup 1/My subgroup 2"
 Group g=this.getSubGroup(MySubPath);
        Parameters:
        _groups - the path of the desired subgroup
        Returns:
        the subgroup
        Since:
        MadKitGroupExtension 1.0

      • getSubGroup

        public Group getSubGroup(Group _group)
        Returns a subgroup contained on this group, or on one of its subgroups. This function is the same call than getSubGroup(false, _group). Here a simple example : 
                Group a=new Group("My community", "A");
  Group aa=new Group("My community", "A", "A");
  Group ba=new Group("My community", "B", "A");
  Group aaba=new Group("My community", "A", "A", "B", "A");
  
  Group subgroup=aa.getSubGroup(ba);
        On this example, the group subgroup is the same group than aaba
        Parameters:
        _group - the subgroup that must be contained into this group.
        Returns:
        the subgroup
        Since:
        MadKitGroupExtension 1.6

      • getSubGroup

        public Group getSubGroup(boolean _isReserved,
                         Group _group)
        Returns a subgroup contained on this group, or on one of its subgroups. Here a simple example : 
                Group a=new Group("My community", "A");
  Group aa=new Group("My community", "A", "A");
  Group ba=new Group("My community", "B", "A");
  Group aaba=new Group("My community", "A", "A", "B", "A");
  
  Group subgroup=aa.getSubGroup(ba);
        On this example, the group subgroup is the same group than aaba
        Parameters:
        _isReserved - tell if the group does not authorize other instances with the same group
        _group - the subgroup that must be contained into this group.
        Returns:
        the subgroup
        Since:
        MadKitGroupExtension 1.6

      • getSubGroup

        public Group getSubGroup(boolean _isReserved,
                         String... _groups)
        Returns a subgroup contained on this group, or on one of its subgroups. Here a simple example : 
                Group a=new Group("My community", "A");
  Group aa=new Group("My community", "A", "A");
  Group ab=new Group("My community", "A", "B");
  Group aba=new Group("My community", "A", "B", "A");
  
  Group subgroup=ab.getSubGroup("A");
        On this example, the group subgroup is the same group than aba Through the function getPath(), you can observe the used String path (containing '/' characters) into MadKit for this group. To convert a String path to a Group class, use this function as follows : 
         String MySubPath="/My subgroup 1/My subgroup 2"
 Group g=this.getSubGroup(_isReserved, MySubPath);
        Parameters:
        _isReserved - tell if the group does not authorize other instances with the same group
        _groups - the path of the desired subgroup
        Returns:
        the subgroup
        Since:
        MadKitGroupExtension 1.0

      • getSubGroupWithItsSubGroups

        public Group getSubGroupWithItsSubGroups(String... _group)
        This function works in the same way that the function getSubGroup(String...). But the return subgroup will also represent its subgroups.
        Parameters:
        _group - the path of the desired subgroup
        Returns:
        the subgroup
        Since:
        MadKitGroupExtension 1.0
        See Also:

      • getSubGroups

        public Group[] getSubGroups(KernelAddress ka)
        This function enable to return all the subgroups of this group, i.e. all the subgroups that are handled by one or more agents.
        Parameters:
        ka - the used kernel address
        Returns:
        the subgroups that are handled by one or more agents, excepted those that are reserved
        Since:
        MadKitGroupExtension 1.0

      • getParentGroups

        public Group[] getParentGroups()
        Return all the parent groups of this group. Note that these parent groups are not necessarily handled by one or more agents.
        Returns:
        all the parent groups of this group excepted those that are reserved. Note that these parent groups are not necessarily handled by one or more agents.
        Since:
        MadKitGroupExtension 1.0

      • getRepresentedGroups

        public Group[] getRepresentedGroups(KernelAddress ka)
        This function returns the represented groups by the current instance. These groups are for the class Group a list of subgroups corresponding to this instance. Only groups that are used on MadKit, i.e. by agents, are returned. Groups that are only instantiated on the program are not returned. If the current instance does not represent its subgroups (see Group(boolean, String, String...)), only one group can be returned at maximum. This group correspond to the current instance. Moreover, if the previous group have not been already handled by one agent, an empty list is returned.
        Specified by:
        getRepresentedGroups in class AbstractGroup
        Parameters:
        ka - the used kernel address.
        Returns:
        the represented groups excepted those that are reserved
        Since:
        MadKitGroupExtension 1.0
        See Also:
        AbstractGroup

      • isUsedSubGroups

        public boolean isUsedSubGroups()

        true if this group represents also its subgroups.
